data.title: Here’s What Data Management Actually Means
data.meta_description: The first step in Data Management is getting your head around the big picture of what is in scope of the term. In this post we apply an industry framework to skim the surface of each topic and cover the full Data Management landscape.
data.text:
How to finally get Data Management

We live in an information economy, one built on top of a web of interconnected data. A web that is growing by 2.5 quintillion (10^18) bytes of data each day. Our lives have become increasingly digital, the world’s biggest companies run on data, and Data Management has never been more important for business.

Research from Mckinsey reports data-driven companies to be 23 times more likely to acquire customers, 6 times likelier to retain them and an incredible 19 times more likely to outperform on profits.

But as businesses invest in their data, they also face the challenges that data brings with it. Data is pervasive — it touches every process in a business. And complexity creeps in when there are different teams or functions responsible for different aspects of Data Management.

The boundaries of where one team stops being responsible and another one starts needs to be clear in order to achieve a good standard of Data Management, but before you can agree firm boundaries you need a complete picture of the capabilites.

In short, a framework is needed.

Data Management Frameworks

The big two: Goliath and Goliath
